This is the date referenced in the article for Benioff’s earlier comments supporting Trump’s use of federal troops, which sparked backlash and prompted the apology on the following day.

keyTakeAways: Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce, initially suggested that President Donald Trump should deploy the National Guard to San Francisco, sparking criticism for implying federal intervention in a local issue.
Benioff later apologized, stating that his comment was made 'from an abundance of caution' and that he had listened to local officials and residents, concluding that the National Guard is not needed.
The annual Dreamforce conference in San Francisco, which drew tens of thousands, provided a context where Benioff’s remarks were amplified and scrutinized.

Benioff's support for Trump’s deployment of federal troops in cities has drawn criticism, including from within his own network—such as venture capitalist Ron Conway quitting the Salesforce Foundation board.

Internal documents suggest Salesforce has previously supported Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) by proposing AI tools for tip evaluation and hiring, raising concerns about corporate ties to immigration enforcement.

Salesforce has historically worked with U.S. federal agencies under previous administrations (Obama and Biden), but the recent reports have intensified scrutiny over its political and policy alignment.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce, initially suggested that President Donald Trump should deploy the National Guard to San Francisco to address safety concerns, a statement that drew widespread criticism. After the Dreamforce conference, which drew tens of thousands, Benioff publicly apologized, stating that the comment was made in caution and that local officials and residents indicated the National Guard was not needed. The controversy also revealed deeper ties between Salesforce and federal immigration enforcement, including internal proposals to support ICE through AI tools, which raised ethical concerns. The backlash included the resignation of venture capitalist Ron Conway from the Salesforce Foundation board, signaling growing unease within the tech community about political alignment. This incident reflects a broader trend of tech billionaires in the Bay Area aligning with President Trump’s policies, raising questions about corporate influence in governance and public safety.
title: Marc Benioff apologizes for suggesting National Guard be sent to San Francisco
